title: Cool URIs Are Human Readable

author: Phil Archer, World Wide Web Consortium (W3C)

segmentation: Think about going later in the day as you have to modify what you're going to say based on other people who said so.
Thank you everybody for saying often what I was going to say.
That's my job.
I want to launch a boat for the World Wide Web Consortium and therefore colleague Richard.
I'm very proud to say, although we do work in different silos and only see each other on all occasions, sometimes very obviously and my work is involved with open data and government data.
So I come across public sector data publishers and so I want to talk a little bit about that work and how it impacts on linked open data as it relates to the topic of today.
Obviously the.
Multilingual web.
So um, recently last year or so I've been working, particularly in a project under the European Commission called the Eyes of program.

This is run not by DG Info as it is for the next few weeks or DG Connect as it will be as of the 1st of July, one of the support part of the Commissioners DG Digit and Digit runs this thing called the interoperability solutions for European Public Administration section which is all about obviously improving interoperability across Europe.

And they do various things, one of which is to fund the project that's run mainly by consultants Pricewaterhouse Coopers who then I work on behalf of W 3 seeking through them and something I've been working on, particularly my own man area is working on some new corporate calories, or rather taking existing vocabularies and defining how public sectors administrations across Europe should use existing for categories to publish their data.
We were looking particularly how to describe a natural person.
Now, this kind of register business and how to describe locations, and in most cases of course the counter is well defined.
The categories exist in a massively use of combos.

There are a few areas where we needed to define some new terms, but in general allotments cover particularly caused by folk and public, or some things are not covered and so we had to define new terms for that.
And since we did a lot of that work recently, I should mention that suggestions classes with us.
He's was one of the members of the Working Group.
And since Moreles finishing that work to three months ago, I spent a lot of time going around Europe talking about this stuff.
I was in the Netherlands recently talking to the overhead Continental people, people who published data on behalf of Netherlands, Denmark last week with the data forum and so on.
So kind of losing track of where I am.
And in doing this work in promoting the use of these core vocabularies obviously depends on the audience you're talking to.
So in the in the Dutch case I was told that most of the audience were not technical specialist at all, so I had to go through a fairly basic bit of what we mean by interoperability.
So so.
Just as an example, using the person vocabulary and so that one of the things we spend a lot of time talking about was how you describe the parts of somebody's name.
Do you use the term first name or full name or Christian mingle?
Given them different Malta?
It's Christian name.
If you're from most of the North of Europe, it's given name and so on.
These things matter culturally.

And if you're talking about how describe a person or things within a small C conservative country in Europe, you will use different terms, even though you're still speaking quote with the same language.

So process of consensus and we end up using the term given name and then of course you have to define it and you say OK if you're giving somebody's given name in a public sector database that you're going to publish, then what we mean by given name is all the given names of that person and give an example of Johan Sebastian Bark and therefore is given a good video and Sebastian trying to make it nice and clear.
Which is correct?
If you speak English.
You're speaking to the Dutch community.
Of course.
You have to try.
Later, because I'm afraid I don't speak Dutch, I had to use Google translation.
If that's wrong, blame Google.
Not me.
It might be horrible if you speak Dutch and apologize and then he goes through the whole thing that we've heard a lot about today.
About how you then turn those, how you attach those labels and those definitions onto a UI.
And in the case of given name, there's one that is extremely well established and is massively used.
It was massively used even before Facebook started using folk and this is the UI.
Anybody with any kind of experience in this field would use to identify the term given name?
Not much doubt about that.
And then you explain OK we can add our labels onto this and we can put the English given name of the Dutch 4 number we can stick with Chinese on if you can pronounce that.
Great I can't.
The point is that we can, as we've heard, put different labels on.
We can translate the descriptions of the definitions, and we can do all that, and we have this nice table you are I.
The URL is really, really, really important.
Remember the audience I was talking to last time was not a technical audience, heard of linked open data.
They've all seen the Elodie cloud.
Mostly haven't got a clue.
Now XML N s.com, which is the domain name used by Dan Bricklin Living Miller when they set up vote roughly a decade ago.
Is happily geographically and politically neutral is not on a.co.uk domain, even though it was developed in Bristol is not on the daay domain which it could have been if it had been here.
It is highly stable.
There's also discussion in this area.
What happens if dam break that goes under a bus?
Well, what happens if Dan Brickley goes under a bus?
Is that somebody else has to pay for XML N s.com to be renewed and that somebody else is the Dublin core metadata initiative.
That is an agreement in place.
If down for whatever reason is unable to continue to continue with both DC and my will take over an it is stable rock solid stable planter, so these are really good things.
So XML N s.com is is OK.
But at the time went down in Libya were working on 4th round about the time they're working on a really big EU project called Sword Europe.
And it's perfectly possible that had dot EU existed.
Then they might have chosen.
They might have chosen XML NS dot EU.
Would have been a reasonable thing to do, given that there is undermining you project.
Most of us have done work or are involved in projects funded by our Dear friends of the Commission.
For that we thank you always and we always build a website ending in dot EU.
If that had been what they had done for folk, do you think the Americans would use it?
The Japanese would use anything ending in DOT A.

You know they're not going to do it, not because it isn't the right thing to do, not because it isn't technically the right thing to do, but because politically nationalistically they're not going to use something that looks foreign.
That looks alien.
So it's really important when you're developing vocabularies that you maintain that political and geographical neutrality.
This is a problem we heard earlier on from Peter Schmitz at the European Publications Office.
They're doing exactly the right thing to do.
Fantastic work they put in ur eyes alongside control for categories.
Their stable.
They've got a UI persistence policy.
It's absolutely the right thing to do except the domain names end in.edu.
Americans aren't going to use some Japanese.
I'm going to use in.
The Australians are confusing, so meeting with some eager people not so long ago talking to the lady from New Zealand.
It is the law was the law there said that if they were to publish any public sector data in New Zealand, the server must physically be located in New Zealand.
Here, but clouds, and not about dumb strings just doesn't apply when you get to politicians and public policy and public sector doesn't work, you have your eyes are brand names.
And although it's annoying for link data purists that mattered.
So OK, thankfully folk of course is is great.
It's actually less XML N s.com and we can use that, but we do still have a bit of a problem.
Because the term is given name.
Now, if you're all in data person, that's OK. You know about both and you're going to use it, and that's fine.
But remember the irrational politicians.
No, this will not go.
Jose was talking about his best practices pulling data.
I agree with everything you said.
Everybody involved with linked data would agree with all the best practices.
He said he listed a number of people at the end that he's spoken to about that they included Richard again.
Yahoo was across the other side of the country in Galway.
Jeni Tennyson, who in my view is one of the most brilliant people involved in this field anywhere.
If you haven't seen legislation.gov.uk, check it out.
It is fantastic everybody legislation passed anywhere in the British Isles since 1247 is in XML.
Whether you are I described in RDF.
It's brilliant engineering.
Those people are the kind of people because they spoke to and got the recommendation that whatever you do, localize the labels.
Don't localize the ur eyes.
That is the right thing to do.
It's also politically naive.
If you are Chinese and you look at XML s.com/info slash 01 given name, it doesn't mean anything to you.
It looks foreign, it looks alien.
So I suggest that maybe I put in Australia maybe.
We might have to commit heresy.
And go against.
What is the best practice for live data?
What is the correct thing to do for big data and do the wrong thing because we can live with it and we could live with the idea of actually localising the bit on the end of the Uri.
We have the technology we have our equivalent property.
Now this has implications if we were to do this.
If we were to do this, then you'd actually put those equivalent terms in the schema itself, which is rather shocking.
That neither focus nor Dublin core has any translation at all.
I think this is bad.
I mean Dublin Corps based in Singapore was developed mainly by a Dutch guy.
I mean why?
Why is why Dublin calls not localized?
I don't know, but the practice is if we were to do this and I understand the heresy and even suggest.
It would mean that of course tools would have to recognize and process that property equivalents quite a lot of them do already know how to talk.
Last week Data Forum in Copenhagen, Worth lady from onto text which produces a triple store called Outlook which is widely used by the BBC and many others.
At ingestion, it does a lot of inference based on RDF subclasses and equivalent properties, and so on, and by doing that you can actually extract more information that may be available in the data.
It is worth doing, and you can get more information out.
Link data people tend to ignore inferencing and tend not to use it, but actually if you do a little bit of influencing particularly and ingestion time, which is when my suggestion.
Of adding in these equivalent properties for localized terms would come in.
That's OK, just generates the triples.
It's more work for vocabulary publishers.
The counter publisher would have to mental as you arise with the localized ends and put in the the.
Equivalence relationships, but it's doable and it's not too far off what's possible.
Now it really isn't, and the important point is that if you are.
Governed by your national policy governed by your National Crime very often.
Or if you're someone like me, governed by your complete monoglot ignorance.
You simply would feel less averse to using these vocabularies.
You feel more comfortable doing it, and that surely would have positive benefit on the interoperability of data, which is what the ISA program and my current work is.
So these with that or.
Maybe I missed that.
